elements.label: header
elements.text:
MAT 186
Quiz 10

elements.label: para
elements.text:
1. Find the volume of the shape created when the region
between $y=2x^2+5x-2$ and $y=4+2x-x^2$ is
rotated about the line $x=1$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: CF9 CS14

elements.label: para
elements.text: We begin by equating the functions and finding where they intersect.

elements.label: fig
elements.text: ![Figure](figures/MAT186H1_20251_63_1748492669769_Quiz_10_-_Solutions_page_001_figure_008.png)

elements.label: para
elements.text: Therefore, $x=-2,1$ are the points of intersection. The volume is:

elements.label: para
elements.text:
2. Find the volume of the shape created when the same region from question 1
is rotated about the line $y=3$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: This is corrected to the line $y=5$, as the lower line intersects the graph.

elements.label: para
elements.text: In that case, we will be dealing with washers.

elements.label: para
elements.text: The outer radius will be $5-(4+2x-x^{2})$ and the inner radius $5-(2x^{2}+5x-2)$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Which is ugly enough to leave alone.

elements.label: foot
elements.text: Continued on back.

elements.label: para
elements.text: 3. A conical tank with height of 3 m and base radius of

elements.label: para
elements.text: CF8 CF9 CS18

elements.label: para
elements.text:
2 m is buried under ground, with its base facing up and 4 m below
ground level. How much work is required to empty the tank through a
pipe 1 m above ground? Leave the density as $\rho$ and the gravity as $g$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: From the diagram, we see the important measurements.

elements.label: fig
elements.text: ![Figure](figures/MAT186H1_20251_63_1748492669769_Quiz_10_-_Solutions_page_002_figure_004.png)

elements.label: para
elements.text:
We can also see two similar triangles that allow us to find
the cross-section area at any height $y$ . The triangles give:

elements.label: para
elements.text: So, $r=\frac{2}{3}y$ and the area of the circle at that height is $A=\frac{4\pi }{9}y^2$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: The distance that the cross-section needs to be moved is

elements.label: para
elements.text: $8-y$, so the total work is

elements.label: equ
elements.text: $$\begin{array} { r l } & { \int _ { 0 } ^ { 3 } \rho g \, \frac { 4 \pi } { 9 } y ^ { 2 } ( 8 - y ) d y } \\ & { = \frac { 4 } { 9 } \pi \rho g \int _ { 0 } ^ { 3 } 8 y ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 3 } d y } \\ & { = \frac { 4 } { 9 } \pi \rho g \left( \frac { 8 } { 3 } y ^ { 3 } - \frac { 1 } { 4 } y ^ { 4 } \right) _ { 0 } ^ { 3 } } \\ & { = \frac { 4 } { 9 } \pi \rho g \left( 7 2 - \frac { 8 1 } { 4 } \right) } \\ & { = 4 \pi \rho g \left( 8 - \frac { 9 } { 4 } \right) } \\ & { = \pi \rho g ( 3 2 - 9 ) } \\ & { = 2 3 \pi \rho g } \end{array}$$

elements.label: para
elements.text:
The last few steps are there to demonstrate how this can be done without resorting to
any three-digit number in your arithmetic.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
[This one is optional. Solve it if you need better marks in the main attribute tested here. If
you try this problem, it will not lower your mark.]

elements.label: sec_1
elements.text:
4. When two numbers are multiplied together, their product is 4. What is the smallest
possible value for their sum?

elements.label: para
elements.text: Let the numbers be $x$ and $y$. Then $xy=4$, or $y=4/x$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: The sum of the numbers is $x+y$, or $x+4/x$.

elements.label: para
elements.text: Set $S'(x) \geq 0$ to find both the critical values and areas of increase and decrease.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
No marks are deducted for assuming that the numbers are positive, but that is not actually
asked for. Keep in mind that "smallest" means closest to zero.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
On a number line, we get the function increasing for $x<-2$ and $x>2$. It is decreasing on
$-2<x<0$ and $0<x<2$.

elements.label: para
elements.text:
At $x=-2$, we have a local maximum of $-4$. At $x=2$, we have a local minimum of $4$. As
$x\to 0$ from either side, the sum diverges to $\pm\infty$. Therefore, these two sums (4 and $-4$) are
the smallest possible values.
